Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Prophylactic Therapy for Postoperative Atrial Fibrillation

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial included patients undergoing cardiac surgery

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a cardiac surgery center, this randomised controlled trial included patients undergoing cardiac surgery

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either prophylactic medical therapy or standard care

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the efficacy of prophylactic medical therapy in reducing the incidence of postoperative AF

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of postoperative AF within 7 days post-surgery

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 420 participants were randomised, with 210 in each group, between January 2020 and June 2021

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 205 participants in the intervention group and 203 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of postoperative AF was significantly lower in the intervention group (17%) compared to the control group (32%), with a risk reduction of 15% (95% CI 8% to 22%; p=0.007)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, primarily mild gastrointestinal side-effects

Funding.evidence: This study was funded by the National Heart Institute
